report_title: Industry at a Glance: Cleaning and Maintenance Supplies Distributors
executive_summary: Cleaning and maintenance supplies distributors sell an array of products drawn from a wide range of markets, including janitorial service companies, commercial and industrial buildings, government buildings, and retail outlets. While demand for cleaning and maintenance supplies is relatively high, enterprises have fierce competition from online and big-box retailers. In the latter part of the period, distributors have experienced a pandemic-induced surge in industry demand due to a jump in the number of businesses. A jump in the number of businesses directly correlates to increased demand for industry services. Overall, industry revenue has climbed at a CAGR of 2.1% to $12.5 billion over the past five years, including a decline of 4.5% in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Growth in Demand Post-Pandemic Supports Industry Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In 2020, health concerns brought on by the pandemic prompted institutions and businesses alike to invest in cleaning supplies more thoroughly, this led to an influx of demand for distributors, specifically in the years post-pandemic. The spike in demand motivated by the pandemic was prolonged as previously constrained government and school budgets experienced a reprieve in the years following 2020. As macroeconomic conditions improved, enabling these markets to bolster their investment in cleaning supplies.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Price Competition Intensifies, Restricting Profit Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry enterprises have struggled to compete with external threats, such as wholesale bypass and e-commerce retailers, resulting in several choosing to slash their prices. Industry participants' input costs have risen, which has only intensified price competition among industry enterprises. Distributor product prices are negotiated item by item and differences are passed on to the customer when possible, making this industry price sensitive. Volatile fuel prices influence transportation expenses incurred by distributors.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: External Competition Poses an Increasingly Existential Threat
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Distributors compete with a host of internal and external competition to appeal to downstream markets. Businesses are the industry's largest downstream markets. These businesses include janitorial service companies, healthcare facilities, service industry businesses, and other retailers. A significant problem arises when cleaning supplies become available at lower prices across internet platforms such as Amazon. More businesses are turning to e-tailers to fulfill their demand for industry products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Positive Economic Trends Will Support the Industry's Growth but E-Commerce Retailers Will Highlight Challenges for Operators
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry is anticipated to continue growing as demand from key markets is expected to grow in addition to positive economic conditions, supporting the industry's growth. Despite interest rates rising and remaining high, specifically at the onset of the outlook period, construction activity is set to improve, boosting the potential for distributors to expand to new businesses. However, as pandemic-related health and safety regulations ease, more businesses and institutions will be less inclined to invest as heavily in cleaning supplies as they did at the height of the pandemic, which will somewhat restrict industry revenue growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: New Entrants Will Seek to Satisfy Growing Demand, Driving Industry Enterprise Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Cleaning and Maintenance Supplies Distributors industry will encounter a jump in industry enterprises as new entrants seek to satisfy the growing demand for industry services. Competition for favorable contracts will likely intensify as more enterprises will compete to obtain larger contracts from suppliers. Suppliers' bargaining power will jump as competition for contracts rises. Price competition will continue to weigh on the industry, causing some cleaning and maintenance supplies distributors to consolidate.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: High Purchase Costs Will Keep Profit Relatively Steady
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Some companies will merge to benefit from economies of scale. Companies will acquire competitors to bolster their market share and improve efficiency, enabling the industry's most prominent enterprises to remain profitable. As industry enterprises climb, there will be greater competition on the basis of price and high purchase costs will wane on industry profit. Larger operators with more significant economies of scale will mitigate this somewhat.

industry_definition: The Cleaning and Maintenance Supplies Distributors industry distributes specialized equipment and supplies for cleaning and maintenance services on a merchant wholesale basis. Products include janitorial and chemical cleaning solutions, waste receptacles and facility maintenance.
key_trends: Competition hinges primarily on price, forcing distributors to make favorable sales terms with existing clients to retain their customer base and potentially attract new clients away from rival companies.
Intense price competition has been a key driver behind consolidation activity.

A broad product portfolio enables distributors to supply and service many companies and industries based on need. Some of the larger companies in the industry can combine high-volume purchasing of cleaning and maintenance supplies with lower prices, adding to their competitive advantage.
Due to consolidation activity, enterprises have struggled with wholesale bypass, resulting in several choosing to slash their prices.
The industry has grown susceptible to external competition from e-commerce retailers, siphoning much of the demand away from cleaning supplies distributors.
The pandemic-induced surge in demand for cleaning supplies presented industry enterprises with a unique opportunity to capitalize on intense demand in the latter part of the period.
Municipal and commercial markets alike have intensified their need for cleaning supplies and supported distributors amid uneasy economic conditions.

Essendant expanded its service offerings to manufacturers with its November 2021 launch of Essendant Fulfillment Services, a third-party logistics solution. Another addition to the company's service portfolio includes customizable marketing solutions.

Veritiv Corporation typically experiences higher net sales in the third and fourth quarters of each year. This volatility has been exacerbated by increased competition from national, local and regional distributors, in addition to independent brokers, catalog-based suppliers, online business-to-business suppliers and manufacturers located throughout the region and nation.
As urbanization and the overall number of businesses continue to consistently grow, a steady stream of demand for cleaning supplies

market_segmentation.segment_description: Retail customers who purchase cleaning supplies to resell them. This segment is decreasing due to e-commerce competition.
Building owners and contractors that source cleaning products and supplies for in-house staff. Share has increased with improved macroeconomic conditions.
Janitorial companies, healthcare centers, service establishments like hotels/restaurants that require cleaning supplies. Largest market segment.
Schools, colleges and universities that require cleaning supplies for classrooms, dorms and buildings. Demand boosted by pandemic.
Other customers not covered in the main segments.

products_and_services.product_description: Chemical cleaners and sanitizers like porcelain bowl sanitizers, odor control products, hard floor chemicals, drain cleaners, and hand sanitizers.

products_and_services.product_or_service: All Janitorial Products, Supplies and Accessories
products_and_services.product_description: Mops, brooms, dusters, squeegees, cleaning gloves, waste handling equipment, and other janitorial cleaning accessories.
Paper towels, facial tissue, toilet tissue, paper napkins, industrial wipers, paper and plastic industrial receptacle liners and packaging products.
Automatic scrubbers, electric floor polishers, power sweepers and other heavy-duty cleaning equipment.
Other janitorial and cleaning products, service receipts, labor charges, and equipment installation.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Janitorial service providers are one of the industry's largest downstream markets. A rise in demand for janitorial services will boost demand for supplies and equipment.

business_locations.location_description: Largest share of establishments due to dense population and downstream markets.
Central hub for businesses and contractors with large cities like New York driving demand.
Highest percentage of establishments and population. Many companies headquartered here to be close to customers.
Home to several manufacturing industries requiring cleaning supplies.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Operators experience low federal regulation. In general, any wholesaling industry is subject to oversight that requires the company to have a wholesaler's license from the US Department of Revenue. This license permits the company to source a product from a manufacturer and sell that product to other businesses. To wholesale and retail their products, distributors in this industry must acquire a retail tax license. Enterprises in this industry are subject to various employment-related laws, including those related to occupational health and safety, wages and overtime.

The cleaning and maintenance products distributed by industry enterprises are subject to light federal oversight. For example, products must meet certain design standards and are classified based on the product's dimensions and other physical characteristics. Many of the industry's products are given performance standards to provide an accurate rating system. Three different bodies develop these standards. The National Fire Protection Association develops industry standards. The American National Standards Institute and its Accredited Standards Committee approves product standards on a national level and the International Organization for Standardization gives these products international standards.

During the pandemic, many state governments imposed rolling social distancing measures to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus. As this industry was categorized as nonessential, industry establishments shuttered temporarily during spring 2020. They reopened facilities with enhanced preventive measures, such as requiring employees to wear face masks and implementing work-from-home measures where possible. Stay-at-home orders nonetheless affected industry enterprises' revenue by causing reductions in demand from retailer end markets.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, contributing to moderate barriers to entry.
The level of industry assistance is low and steady, indicating moderate barriers.

factors_decreased_barrier: Capital intensity level is low, decreasing barriers.
Concentration level is low, decreasing barriers.
Technology change level is low, decreasing barriers.
Globalization level is low and steady, decreasing barriers.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition hinges primarily on price, forcing distributors to make favorable sales terms to retain and attract customers.
Intense price competition has been a key driver behind industry consolidation activity.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The local nature of cleaning supplies distribution contributes to low market concentration.
The industry encounters consolidation as large operators seek to expand market share, pressuring smaller enterprises.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases account for the bulk of the industry's expenses
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases account for the bulk of the industry's expenses, comprising roughly two-thirds of industry revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The initial purchase of cleaning and maintenance supplies
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The initial purchase of cleaning and maintenance supplies from upstream producers constitutes one of the most critical aspects of doing business in this industry, as prices paid for inventory will dictate the potential profit margin realized after a sale.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The price of industry-related supplies and volatile inputs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The price of industry-related supplies and volatile inputs such as fuel costs for transportation have risen, increasing operating costs for industry enterprises.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Broad Downstream Markets Control Against Fluctuations in Demand
volatility_points.volatility_description: The Cleaning and Maintenance Supplies Distributors industry exhibits a moderate level of revenue volatility, which reflects variations in the level of demand from a wide-array of downstream customers, of which a number are exposed to cyclical forces.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Purchase Cost Inflation and Volatility Affect Industry Performance
volatility_points.volatility_description: Fluctuations in cleaning and maintenance supply costs also contribute to the industry's volatility, though demand for cleaning supplies is relatively steady. As volatile input prices, such as fuel, have recently surged, the industry has incurred high purchase costs, ultimately pressuring profit, restricting growth.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Improvements in Communication Technology Aim to Streamline Sales
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Most of the capital improvements within the wholesaling industry have focused on introducing or upgrading communications technology. Communications technology can improve sales and help manage inventory levels. In addition, communications technology can improve efficiency among operators.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Advanced Inventory Controls Present Distributors With an Opportunity to Improve Operational Efficiency
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: With better inventory controls, sales and inventory levels are more efficiently implemented. This technology includes online services that enable customers to search inventory, lists that check pricing and product location and online billing.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain a competitive edge against competitors?
FAQs.answer: Many operators compete by trying to offering more efficient distribution.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on any one market, major customer or other isolated revenue stream?
FAQs.answer: Some operators specialize in only a few types of products and therefore cater to a single market.

FAQs.question: How does the size of your company affect its profitability and growth potential?
FAQs.answer: Large operators are able to operate more extensive distribution networks.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored growth opportunities via mergers or acquisitions?
FAQs.answer: Large operators look to acquire small distributors and consolidate operations.

FAQs.question: How has your company been able to implement technology into the purchasing process to make buying more efficient for customers?
FAQs.answer: Inventory management systems have helped many operators better manage their products and sales.

FAQs.question: Does your company currently have an e-commerce platform for volume sales? If not, do you have plans to create one?
FAQs.answer: Online sales have allowed operators to reduce their wage costs and improve their profit margins.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all relevant health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Operators must ensure that all products are up to safety standards, because these products are used by dangerous industries.

FAQs.question: What is your company policy on hazardous material handling and remediation?
FAQs.answer: Most states regulate the distribution of certain products, placing the burden of compliance on industry operators.

FAQs.question: What cost-saving measures do you currently employ, and what measures might you implement in the future?
FAQs.answer: Many industry operators use inventory management systems and digital sales systems, reducing operating costs.

FAQs.question: How does volatility in the value of the dollar affect demand and profit?
FAQs.answer: As the dollar appreciates, imports increase, creating competition for operators.

FAQs.question: What do you do to promote loyalty and to keep your customers returning for follow-up visits? How do you collect customer feedback?
FAQs.answer: Companies in the Cleaning and Maintenance Supplies Distributors industry must maintain a consistent customer base for repeat sales.

FAQs.question: Do you have any deals with other companies involving technology sharing? Can you use these systems to approach new potential partners?
FAQs.answer: The integration of computer technologies between manufacturers and wholesalers can lower costs.

FAQs.question: Do you have large contracts in comparison with your competitors? What do you do to attract and maintain sizable orders?
FAQs.answer: Cleaning and maintenance supplies distributors must maintain a working relationship and large supply contract with various manufacturers of industry goods.

FAQs.question: How will a changing urban population affect your company? Are you located somewhere to take advantage of the urban market?
FAQs.answer: As more people move to metropolitan areas, the need for cleaning services, and thus supplies, for public areas such as subway stations and parks, increases.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand when disposable income levels rise? How much of your business goes to retail outlets?
FAQs.answer: The industry is sensitive to changes in household disposable income, which is, in turn, affected by changes in general employment and tax and interest rates. It has a direct effect on demand for value-added services, purchases of merchandise and, to some extent, the frequency of use of services.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your sales are derived from janitorial service providers? How can you establish more business relationships in this sector?
FAQs.answer: A rise in demand for janitorial service providers will increase the amount of janitorial equipment and supplies that this industry distributes.
